For me this year it has been about 10 mins of yoga each day  ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs been a hard August and I am unable to do as much as I have in previous years ‚Ä¶ but want to thank everyone who has taken part in #NursesActive for inspiring me.

#NursesActive is all about just being a little more active. It‚Äôs not about running marathons. It‚Äôs not about being the best, the fittest or the fastest.  It‚Äôs about moving a little more in August ‚Ä¶ whatever that may mean to you

RT @SavineLouise: @WeNurses Prevent, prevent, prevent. Document everything you do and ensure you give individualised patient care. #bekind‚Ä¶

@Charlot49760636 @WeNurses working in social care and across 7 homes / reablement service we find that no one thing works .... multiple approaches - quizzes, posters, notice boards, sharing research in journal clubs, 1:1 sessions, robust auditing and feedback, sharing case studies #WeNurses

Pressure injuries ... identify those at risk early on, use clinical judgement, use a robust tool that is suitable for the people you are caring for .... and i know it's a strapline but 'react to red' #WeNurses https://t.co/tpPk6CmmhY

So much can affect a person's risk of pressure injury ... It's really important to ensure we act quickly and with sound clinical judgement.   Tools can help but not a replacement for nursing expertise #WeNurses

@pauljebb1 I get what you are saying ‚Ä¶. But why is it that when we assess someone‚Äôs BP and it‚Äôs high we act on it ‚Ä¶. When we assess someone‚Äôs pain and it‚Äôs high we don‚Äôt ‚Ä¶. Why is it the process gets in the way of one but nothing the other ??

@alisonleary1 @markjdoughty I find myself saying this a lot lately ‚Ä¶. But we need to take a person centred approach to staff in the same way we do patients ‚Ä¶. How often do we ask ‚Äúhow can we support you?‚Äù And really mean it !

Eventually a doctor came, followed by an anaesthetist and he pain subsided.  But all the time we heard nurses come and switch off his call bell and do nothing, we heard them take blood and take obs and not inform him.  No one spoke to him and no one cared

We heard as nurses told him that he had had enough pain relief and wasn‚Äôt prescribed anything else.  He was screaming in pain saying that he wanted to die and nurses did nothing.  We had to call the ward and tell them that he needed to see a doctor but still they delayed

It‚Äôs with a really heavy heart that I wake this morning as I feel that nursing, nurses and the ward at @uhbwNHS have utterly failed my son.  He called us at midnight in extreme pain, and for three hours we had to listen to huge nursing failures in regard to our sons care ‚Ä¶.
